US_CA.label: California, US
US_CA.notes: California taxes capital gains as ordinary income. Highest state rate in the US at 13.3% (includes 1% Mental Health Services surtax on income over $1M).
US_CA.quirks: No preferential capital gains rate at state level. All gains taxed as ordinary income. At 50.3% combined short-term rate, every dollar of short-term gain costs twice what it would in Texas. Does not conform to federal QSBS exclusion.

US_NY.label: New York, US
US_NY.notes: New York state top rate is 10.9% on income over $25M. NYC residents face an additional city tax of up to 3.876%.
US_NY.quirks: NYC residents face a combined rate up to 51.8% on short-term gains when city tax is included. Even outside NYC, the 'tax benefit recapture' provision means high earners effectively pay top rate on all income, not just the amount above the threshold.

US_NJ.label: New Jersey, US
US_NJ.notes: New Jersey top rate of 10.75% applies to income over $1M. Progressive brackets from 1.4% to 10.75%.
US_NJ.quirks: NJ does not allow tax loss carryback — losses can only offset future gains. This makes tax loss harvesting timing especially critical for NJ traders who have a bad year.

US_IL.label: Illinois, US
US_IL.notes: Illinois has a flat 4.95% income tax rate. Capital gains taxed as ordinary income.
US_IL.quirks: Flat tax means no bracket management benefit. The same 4.95% applies whether you make $50K or $5M in gains. This simplifies tax planning but eliminates any bracket-based optimization strategies.

US_MA.label: Massachusetts, US
US_MA.notes: Massachusetts taxes short-term capital gains at 8.5% and long-term at 5% base rate. A 4% millionaire surtax applies on all taxable income over $1,083,150, bringing effective top rates to 12.5% (ST) and 9% (LT).
US_MA.quirks: Unique among US states: Massachusetts has DIFFERENT state rates for short-term vs long-term gains. Short-term gains face 12.5% state tax (with surtax) vs 9% for long-term. This makes the holding period decision worth an extra 3.5% at the state level alone, on top of the 17% federal difference.

US_TX.label: Texas, US
US_TX.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only.

US_FL.label: Florida, US
US_FL.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only.

US_WA.label: Washington, US
US_WA.notes: No state income tax. However, Washington imposes a 7% excise tax on long-term capital gains exceeding $278,000 (9.9% on gains above $1M). Short-term gains are not subject to the state tax.
US_WA.quirks: Washington's capital gains tax only hits long-term gains above $278,000, so smaller traders pay federal rates only. But high-earning traders face a surprise 7-9.9% state tax despite Washington's reputation as a no-income-tax state. This effectively makes WA's long-term rate 27-29.9% for large gains.

US_NV.label: Nevada, US
US_NV.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only.

US_TN.label: Tennessee, US
US_TN.notes: No state income tax. Hall Tax on interest and dividends was fully repealed in 2021. Federal rates only.

US_WY.label: Wyoming, US
US_WY.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only.

US_CT.label: Connecticut, US
US_CT.notes: Connecticut top rate of 6.99% with 7 progressive brackets. Capital gains taxed as ordinary income.
US_CT.quirks: Connecticut's 'tax benefit recapture' provision can cause high-income taxpayers to lose the benefit of lower brackets, effectively paying the top 6.99% rate on all income. Tax planning that pushes income across recapture thresholds can trigger disproportionate state tax increases.

US_PA.label: Pennsylvania, US
US_PA.notes: Pennsylvania has a flat 3.07% income tax. Capital gains taxed as ordinary income. No standard deduction or personal exemption at state level.
US_PA.quirks: Philadelphia residents pay an additional 3.75% city wage tax. PA's flat 3.07% is among the lowest state income tax rates, but the lack of standard deduction means the first dollar of gains is taxed.

US_OH.label: Ohio, US
US_OH.notes: Ohio has a 2-bracket system: 2.75% on income $26,050-$100K, 3.125% on income over $100K. Moving to flat 2.75% in 2026.
US_OH.quirks: Ohio municipal income taxes (up to 3% in some cities) can add to the effective rate. Business income is taxed separately at a flat 3%. The state is actively reducing rates toward a flat 2.75%.

US_CO.label: Colorado, US
US_CO.notes: Colorado has a flat 4.4% income tax. Capital gains taxed as ordinary income.
US_CO.quirks: Colorado offers a capital gains subtraction for qualifying Colorado-source gains on assets held for at least one year, which can reduce the effective state rate on some investments.

US_GA.label: Georgia, US
US_GA.notes: Georgia recently moved to a flat 5.19% tax rate (reduced from 5.39% in 2024). Rate is scheduled to drop 0.10% per year until reaching 4.99%.
US_GA.quirks: Georgia's declining rate schedule means timing large gains to later years could save 0.10% per year at the state level. The transition from progressive to flat tax also eliminated bracket management strategies.

US_NC.label: North Carolina, US
US_NC.notes: North Carolina has a flat 4.25% income tax (reduced from 4.5% in 2024). Dropping to 3.99% in 2026.
US_NC.quirks: NC's rapidly declining rate schedule (was 5.25% in 2022, heading to 3.99% in 2026) means deferring gains to future years has a measurable state tax benefit.

US_VA.label: Virginia, US
US_VA.notes: Virginia top rate of 5.75% on income over $17,000. Progressive 4-bracket system but top bracket kicks in very low.
US_VA.quirks: Virginia's top 5.75% rate kicks in at just $17,000 of taxable income — virtually all traders with any gains pay the top rate. This makes Virginia's progressive brackets effectively flat for anyone with meaningful trading income.

US_AZ.label: Arizona, US
US_AZ.notes: Arizona has a flat 2.5% income tax, one of the lowest state income tax rates in the country.
US_AZ.quirks: Arizona's 2.5% flat rate is low enough that state tax optimization provides minimal benefit. The 17% federal difference between short-term and long-term rates dominates any tax planning decision.

US_OR.label: Oregon, US
US_OR.notes: Oregon top rate of 9.9% on income over $125K (single) / $250K (MFJ). No state sales tax.
US_OR.quirks: Oregon has no sales tax, so income and capital gains taxes are the primary state revenue source — making future rate increases more likely than in states with diversified tax bases. The 9.9% rate makes Oregon the third-highest state for capital gains after California and Massachusetts.

US_SD.label: South Dakota, US
US_SD.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only.

US_AK.label: Alaska, US
US_AK.notes: No state income tax. No state capital gains tax. Federal rates only. Residents receive an annual Permanent Fund Dividend.

US_NH.label: New Hampshire, US
US_NH.notes: No state income tax. The Interest and Dividends Tax was fully repealed effective 2025. Federal rates only.

RO.label: Romania
RO.notes: Securities via Romanian brokers: 1% if held 365+ days, 3% if held under 365 days. Transactions not via broker: 10% flat. Additional 10% CASS health contribution on gains above 6x minimum wages.
RO.quirks: Romania's 1% long-term rate is among the lowest in the world for active traders. However, the 10% CASS health contribution on gains above roughly EUR 20,000 effectively raises the rate significantly. Traders using non-Romanian brokers face a flat 10% rate regardless of holding period. The holding period distinction makes Romania one of few countries where extending holds has a 3x tax rate reduction.

SG.label: Singapore
SG.notes: Zero capital gains tax. However, gains from frequent or systematic trading may be reclassified as business income and taxed at personal income tax rates (up to 22%).
SG.quirks: Zero capital gains tax sounds like paradise, but Singapore's IRAS can reclassify frequent traders as conducting a business. Indicators include: trading as primary income source, high frequency, short holding periods, use of leverage, and systematic methodology. If reclassified, gains face up to 22% income tax. Day traders and very active swing traders are most at risk of reclassification.

UK.label: United Kingdom
UK.notes: Capital gains tax at 24% for higher/additional rate taxpayers, 18% for basic rate taxpayers. Annual CGT allowance of GBP 3,000 before tax applies. No distinction between short-term and long-term holding periods.
UK.quirks: The UK has NO holding period distinction — a stock held 1 day and a stock held 10 years face the same 24% rate. This means holding period extension advice is irrelevant for UK traders. Instead, the GBP 3,000 annual exempt amount makes timing of gain realization critical — spreading sales across tax years to stay under the allowance each year is the primary optimization. The allowance was slashed from GBP 12,300, so most active traders will exceed it.

DE.label: Germany
DE.notes: Flat 26.375% Abgeltungsteuer (25% withholding tax + 5.5% solidarity surcharge). Church tax members pay an additional 8-9% of the base 25%. Tax-free allowance of EUR 1,000 per person.
DE.quirks: Germany's flat withholding tax means no holding period benefit — short and long-term gains are taxed identically at 26.375%. However, cryptocurrency held over 1 year is completely tax-free, creating an unusual incentive for crypto vs equity allocation. The Gunstigerpruefung allows taxpayers with a marginal rate below 25% to use their lower personal rate instead. Church tax can push the effective rate to ~28.6%.

AU.label: Australia
AU.notes: Capital gains included in assessable income at marginal rates (top rate 45% + 2% Medicare levy = 47%). 50% CGT discount for assets held over 12 months, making the effective top long-term rate ~23.5%.
AU.quirks: Australia's 50% CGT discount is one of the most generous long-term holding incentives globally — it literally halves the tax. This creates an enormous cliff at the 12-month mark: selling at 11 months means 47% tax, selling at 12 months means 23.5%. For Australian traders, the holding period decision is worth more than in almost any other jurisdiction. The discount applies to individuals only, not companies or trusts.

JP.label: Japan
JP.notes: Flat 20.315% on all securities gains (15% national + 0.315% reconstruction surtax + 5% local inhabitants tax). No holding period distinction for securities.
JP.quirks: Japan's flat 20.315% rate with no holding period distinction means tax optimization focuses entirely on NISA (tax-exempt investment accounts) rather than holding period. NISA allows up to JPY 3.6M/year in new investments with tax-free gains. The reconstruction surtax (for 2011 earthquake rebuilding) runs until 2037. Real estate gains have very different (and much higher) short-term rates.

CAN.label: Canada
CAN.notes: 50% capital gains inclusion rate — only half of gains are added to taxable income. Top combined federal+provincial rate varies by province (Ontario example: 53.53% marginal x 50% inclusion = 26.76% effective). Proposed increase to 66.67% inclusion was cancelled in 2025.
CAN.quirks: Canada's 50% inclusion rate means the effective tax rate is always half the marginal income tax rate. The proposed increase to 66.67% inclusion was cancelled by PM Carney in 2025, but the political risk remains — future governments may revisit. The Lifetime Capital Gains Exemption of $1,250,000 on qualified small business shares is a powerful planning tool. No distinction between short-term and long-term holding periods.

CH.label: Switzerland
CH.notes: Private capital gains on securities are tax-free. However, traders classified as 'professional' (gewerbsmassiger Wertschriftenhandler) are taxed at income tax rates (up to ~40% depending on canton).
CH.quirks: Switzerland's zero capital gains tax only applies to private investors. Five criteria determine professional classification: holding period under 6 months, transaction volume exceeding 5x portfolio value per year, gains exceeding 50% of total income, use of leverage/margin, and significant use of derivatives. Crossing these thresholds triggers full income taxation at cantonal rates up to ~40%. This creates a hard behavioral ceiling — Swiss traders must carefully monitor their trading frequency and leverage use.

HK.label: Hong Kong
HK.notes: Zero capital gains tax under Hong Kong's territorial tax system. Only Hong Kong-sourced employment income is taxed (capped at 15%).
HK.quirks: Hong Kong has zero capital gains tax with no professional trader reclassification risk (unlike Singapore and Switzerland). This makes it one of the most genuinely tax-free jurisdictions for active trading. Share-based compensation (RSUs, stock options) is taxed as employment income upon vesting. No withholding tax on dividends or interest from HK-listed securities.

AE.label: United Arab Emirates
AE.notes: Zero personal income tax and zero capital gains tax. A 9% corporate tax was introduced in 2023 on business profits over AED 375,000, but does not apply to individual investment gains.
AE.quirks: The UAE has zero personal capital gains tax with no reclassification risk for individuals. The 2023 corporate tax introduction signals a possible future shift, but individual traders remain fully exempt. Free zone entities may still access 0% corporate tax. No tax on dividends, interest, or capital gains for individuals.
